---
layout: post
title: To Default or Not to Default
subtitle: That Is the Question. A Look at Historical Loans of the SBA
cover-img: /assets/img/loan-application.jpg
thumbnail-img: /assets/img/small-business-loan.png
share-img: /assets/img/small-business-loan.jpg
tags: [classification, machine learning]
---


The Small Business Administration (SBA) is a federal agency in the United States founded by former president Eisenhower to aid support small businesses nationwide. It’s no secret that small businesses are a staple of every economy. They create employment opportunities and are usually involved with their communities. As of the time period used for this research, the SBA’s Office of Advocacy [released a report](https://advocacy.sba.gov/2018/12/19/advocacy-releases-small-business-gdp-1998-2014/) showing how small businesses account for 44% of U.S economic activity and create 66% of net new jobs, essentially dubbed the lifeblood of the economy.



![SBA GDP](https://cdn.advocacy.sba.gov/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/16164712/Featured-image1-750x430.png)

This is an image from the SBA's Office of Advocacy report showing how small businesses aid to push the GDP of Large businesses.



One of the ways the SBA assists small businesses is of course, financial aid. The SBA has some loan programs such as a [disaster loan](https://www.sba.gov/funding-programs/disaster-assistance) for different types of declared disasters (from physical to economic injury). Probably the most common loan program is the [SBA Loan](https://www.sba.gov/funding-programs/loans), which works through lenders collaborating with the SBA. The SBA guarantees a portion of the loan, essentially becoming a sort of insurance provider. If the loan exceeds maturity and defaults, the SBA covers the guaranteed amount. It is definitely an interesting concept and there have been successful start-ups taking advantage of this such as FedEx and Apple. Naturally, there have also been small businesses defaulting on this loan. This results in banks still being skeptical of approving loans because they stand to lose a good bit of money if the loan defaults despite the guarantee. Consider that some of these loans can go as high as [$5.5 million](https://www.sba.gov/funding-programs/loans).

There are [multiple schools of thought](https://amstat.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/10691898.2018.1434342) on this concept. Some argue that the banks, lenders, and credit market as a whole perform efficiently on their own without government intervention. Some argue that the benefits of small businesses outweigh the costs of any defaults. As interested as I am in business, the purpose of this research was not to pick a side in the debate. I’ll leave that to my brother and his business school classmates. I decided to look at historical data of the SBA Loan program from 1984 to 2014 and develop a model that would predict if a small business would default on its loan.

Without going too much into the technical details (for the technical oriented, you can check out my [GitHub](https://github.com/ik-okoro/SBA-Loans), I had some ideas to create new features for the model to train on. One of those was if the loan was approved or received during a recession. I used the 90s recession, the early 2000s recession, and of course the Great Recession. I also checked if the bank State was in the same State as the business. Several other factors were generated such as binned loan term. You can compare graphs for original features in the SBA National Report file and extra features in the SBA National Report New Features file in my [GitHub](https://github.com/ik-okoro/SBA-Loans).

![Classification Report](data:image/png;base64,)

Can see my model had an F1-score of 90% with a precision of 91%. What I am most concerned with is the recall of 88%. With this, my model clears 12% of loans that would default. I don’t think that is good enough with the amounts of money these banks deal with. It would have helped if I had a link to the SBA that had knowledge of how the record of how the data was collected. In that case, I could get clarifications rather than making assumptions, which would result in a better model. A missing piece is also features on demographics and the business itself. Potentially stronger businesses would show it in their financials and thus improve the model. Note also that the data does not factor those that arranged to refinance or extend their maturity date (0r if it did, did not show it).

Considering this was a base model there could me multiple things I could do to improve those scores. I could consider not dropping the name of banks as a feature and use that to compare size of the lender. I could also consider inflation, drop actual dollar amounts, and use percentages instead. This model also granted equal weight to each recession so I could assign weights due to the magnitude of the Great Recession. These are ideas to work on and if I can get the scores up, I’ll be comfortable deploying a web app that would result in higher precision but more importantly, recall.


References:

List of recessions in the United States. (2020, October 19). Retrieved October 22, 2020, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_recessions_in_the_United_States

Min Li, Amy Mickel & Stanley Taylor (2018) “Should This Loan be Approved or Denied?”: A Large Dataset with Class Assignment Guidelines, Journal of Statistics Education, 26:1, 55-66, DOI: 10.1080/10691898.2018.1434342

US Small Business Administration (2020), retrieved October 21, 2020 from https://www.sba.gov

US Small Business Administration Office of Advocacy (2020), retrieved October 21, 2020 from https://advocacy.sba.gov/about/
